context: The Estonian word 'kardab' is the third person singular present tense form of the verb 'kartma', which means 'to fear' or 'to be afraid of'. It's used when talking about someone else who experiences fear. The root word 'kart-' appears in various forms: kartma (infinitive), kardan (I fear), kardad (you fear), kardab (he/she/it fears), kardame (we fear), kardate (y'all/plural you fear), kardavad (they fear).
